newsitem.title: USA: US Plains cattle markets quiet, few $70 bids-trade.
newsitem.headline: US Plains cattle markets quiet, few $70 bids-trade.

text.p: U.S. Plains feedlot cattle markets were quiet early Wednesday as feedlot managers again passed $70.00 per cwt bids, feedlot sources said.
"It is not doing any good," said a Texas manager of the $70 bids. "We continue to price cattle at $73.00."
A small number of cattle sold in Kansas Tuesday at $73.00, but sources said special circumstances were probably associated with those trades.
Kansas sources also reported passing scattered $70.00 bids early Wednesday. Although cattle were priced at $73.00, one manager said "$72.00 is probably more realistic."

USDA reported beef cutout values jumped Tuesday $2.00 to $2.14 per cwt on choice cuts and were $0.69 to $0.78 higher for select beef. Cutout values for choice yield-grade 1-3 700-850 lb carcasses were quoted at $118.89 per cwt -- the highest level since June 1993, USDA confirmed.
